intro: Fragaria vesca intermedia, commonly known as the woodland strawberry, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring trifoliate leaves with serrated edges and small, white flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant produces aggregate fruits composed of numerous small, bright red berries, each containing a single seed. It thrives in partial shade and well-drained soil, often found in forest understories and rocky habitats. Its botanical features make it a valuable species for ecological studies and horticultural cultivation.
